Award.AwardTitle: CIF: Medium: Collaborative Research: Estimating simultaneously structured models: from phase retrieval to network coding

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
In modern data-intensive science and engineering, researchers are faced with estimating models where available observations are far fewer than the dimension of the model to be estimated. The key to the success of compressed sensing, matrix completion, and other problems of this type, is to properly exploit knowledge about the "structure" of the model. While structures such as sparsity have been separately studied, the problem of "simultaneous structures" has been neglected, since it is implicitly assumed by practitioners that simply combining known results for each structure would solve the joint problem. Interestingly, the PIs recently proved that this approach can result in a significant gap.

This proposal will develop theory and computationally tractable methods for estimating simultaneously structured models with minimal observations. It combines (1) a top-down approach to understand the fundamental limitations based on the geometry of how structures interact, and (2) a problem-specific, bottom-up approach to exploit domain knowledge in constructing appropriate penalties. This work addresses a variety of applications including (1) sparse principal component analysis, a central problem in statistics seeking approximate but sparse eigenvectors, (2) sparse phase retrieval and quadratic compressed sensing in signal processing, and (3) code design for communications and network coding.

The ability to systematically derive structured models from data will have far-reaching impact on engineering challenges in the era of Big Data and ubiquitous computing. Handling models with multiple structures poses deep theoretical and computational challenges that this proposal focuses on. Applications in machine learning, signal processing, and network coding are discussed. The PIs will incorporate research results in their teaching, organize technical workshops to bring together mathematicians and engineers, and seek the involvement of undergraduate students in this work through summer research programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In modern data-intensive science and engineering, one is faced with constructing models/signals with limited information. The challenge lies in ill-posedness: available observations are often far fewer than the dimension of the model to be estimated. The key to the success in problems of this type, is prior knowledge about model structure.


While a general theory on how to recover signals that have a signal structure (sparse, low rank, constant modulus, etc.) from limited (i.e., compressed) measurements has emerged in the last few years, we still do not know how to optimally do so for signals that have multiple structures. Such signals arise in many applications, such as communications where we encounter signals that are simultaneosuly sparse and finite alphabet, in machine learning where we encounter sparse measurements of graphs that need to be clustered, in sparse phase retrieval, where we encounter matrices that are simultaneously sparse and rank one, and in network coding and distributed storage where one encounters matrices that are simultaneously low rank and finite field.


For signals with a single structure, recovery is performed by minimizing a cost function that includes a convex regularizer to "promote" the desired structure. For signals with multiple structures, it was long assumed that all one needs to do is to add the (appropriately-weighted) regularizers to the cost function. In recent work, we have shown that this approach can be highly suboptimal, in the sense that the number of measurements required for successful signal recovery can be much larger than the "degrees of freedom" of the simultaneously-structured signal.


The goal of this project was to study the fundamental limits for the recovery of simultaneosuly-structured signals, as well as to develop efficient algorithms. We did this both in a general context, as well as in each of the specific cases of interest.

The outcomes included new algorithms for phase retrieval with provable guarantees. We should that the phase of an unknown signal can be uniquely, efficiently, and robustly recovered by three carefully designed phaseless measurements. We developed a new modulation scheme, called MOCZ (modulation on conjugated zeros), which is a very promising candidate for Internet-of-Things communications that is bursty, short-packet, and machine-to-machine. We developed new methods for efficient crowd-sourced clustering, based on triangle queries. And finally, we solved a lone standing open conjecture in coding theory, the GM-MDS conjecture, which has significant ramifications in distributed storage, multiple access channels, and weakly secure data exchange.
